behavior is usually ascribed to TLL physics, whereas the nonmetallic
To gain more insight into the nature of the electronic state below
, we have investigated the angle-dependent MR (ADMR) in
(details of the resistivity measurements can be found in Materials
and Methods). The angles of orientation of
pal planes colored in Fig. 2A are specified by
the manuscript. Figure 2B shows the temperature evolution of the
minima and maxima whenever the field is oriented along
respectively. As shown in the left-hand panel of Fig. 2C, upon
, the two traces are perfectly super-
imposed, implying a fully symmetric response. With decreasing
temperature however, the positions of the maxima (and, to a lesser
extent, the minima) begin to shift away from the crystallographic
axes. The developing asymmetry is most illustrated in the reflection
plot, shown in the right-hand panel of Fig. 2C for
sponding reflection plots for a number of intermediate temperatures
In general, the MR of a monoclinic crystal is asymmetric, with
angle in LMO is so small (~0.61°) that the system can be taken to be
orthorhombic within experimental uncertainty. This agrees well with
the experimentally observed mirror symmetry of MR at high tem-
perature and with the theoretically calculated Fermi surface (
The unexpected breaking of the mirror symmetry at low tempera-
ture, nonetheless, points to a marked change in the electronic
structure that can be enhanced by strong magnetic fields.
To quantify this unusual asymmetric response, we plot in
Fig. 2D the integrated area (shaded area in the right-hand panel of
Fig. 2C) between the two reflections normalized to the magnitude
of the MR (i.e., the difference between the resistivity values at
). The inset in Fig. 2D shows a blowup of the region
between 10 and 40 K. A clear onset in the asymmetry is revealed at
= 24 ± 1 K, implying that it is intimately
connected to the resistivity upturn at
resembles that of an order parameter.
Below 10 K however, the asymmetry grows much more steeply
(see the main panel of Fig. 2D for
This asymmetric MR is found to be independent of current di-
rection. Figure 2E shows the evolution of the ADMR within the
are shown in fig. S3). Above
the mirror symmetry is preserved with respect to the crystallo-
, the asymmetric behavior is observed at all
temperatures. The magnitude of the asymmetry, however, does
depend on the field strength. Fig. 2F shows the enhanced asymmetry
with increasing field up to 30 T measured on a different LMO crystal
= 1.2 K (see almost identical behavior in Fig. 3B for another
insulating crystal and in fig. S6b for a second, superconducting
crystal). As the field increases, the position of the maximum MR
shifts away from the crystallographic axes. Notably, when the
magnetic field is rotated within the
cernible shift in the position of the maxima/minima across
(see also figs. S3 and S4). No shift is found either with increasing
field strength (fig. S5). Such a dependence of the asymmetric MR on
the specific plane of rotation places strong constraints on any effective
theory put forward to explain this effect.
To gain deeper insight into how the asymmetry develops with
-field, we have performed a series of MR sweeps as a
function of magnetic field oriented at multiple angles within the
plane. Fig. 3A shows results for a nonsuperconducting sample
a superconducting sample is plotted in fig. S6). In the low-
) follows a quadratic dependence in field and scales
small negative offset, suggesting that it originates from the effects of
Fig. 1. Crystal structure, band structure, and metal-insulator transition of LMO.
) Projection of four unit cells onto the
the conducting zigzag chains (oriented out of this plane along the
axis) are highlighted in purple. Blue sphere, Mo; red/pink, O; green, Li. (
) In each unit cell, there are
double zigzag chains made of corner-sharing octahedra. The octahedra at the top of the figure have had all nonessential oxygen atoms removed. The corner oxygen
shared by adjacent in-chain octahedra is denoted in red, while interchain oxygen is denoted in pink. (
) Simplified Fermi surface of LMO showing the weakly dispersive,
axis due to the weak interchain hopping energy (top panel), which, nevertheless, causes an energy gap around the Fermi surface (schematic
green curves in the lower panel). The small energy gap easily allows excitation of electron-hole pairs, i.e., excitons. (
) In-chain resistivity versus temperature showing a
~ 25 K, below which the insulating form of the resistivity can be well fitted by a power law (see section S4C and fig. S11). Crystallo-
graphic drawings were produced using VESTA (
